newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian cargo plane crashes in Siberia - agency.
newsitem.headline: Russian cargo plane crashes in Siberia - agency.

text.p: A Russian air force Ilyushin Il-76 cargo plane with 19 people aboard crashed in Siberia on Wednesday night, Interfax news agency reported.
Interfax said the Emergency Services Ministry in Moscow had confirmed the crash.
Officials at the ministry, who had earlier told Reuters the plane was missing, were not available to confirm the report.

Interfax said rescuers had found wreckage and several bodies 16 km (10 miles) from the airport at Abakan in southern Siberia, where the plane had taken off on a flight to the far eastern Kamchatka peninsula.
The four-engined jet, carrying six crew, 13 passengers and 30 tonnes of commercial freight, left Abakan at 1647 GMT, a ministry spokesman said.
"They lost contact seven minutes later," she added.
The Il-76, designed as a military tank transporter, is a mainstay of Russia's armed forces and of its commercial fleet.
It is not unusual for military planes to be contracted out for private ventures as servicemen struggle to make ends meet amid Russia's economic crisis.
The Il-76, with its distinctive low-slung fuselage and bulbous glass nose-cone, has become a familiar sight on the world's freight routes since the collapse of the Soviet Union.

A number have been involved in accidents in recent months, including a civilian freighter owned by the Kazakh airline KazAir, which was involved in the world's worst mid-air collision with a Saudi jumbo jet near Delhi on November 12.

Last April, an Il-76 came down on Kamchatka, killing all aboard. One came down near Belgrade in August, killing 10 crewmen and a Ukrainian crew died when their Il-76 crashed on take-off at Kinshasa in June.
A surge in air accidents in Russia in the past few years has been blamed on financial difficulties, which have led to poor maintenance standards and placed extra pressure on crews.
